We are working more on derivatives, with a relatively low level of value at risk, as you have seen. And so we have said that as far as our market are concerned, and yes it's mostly fixed income, there are additional risk-weighted assets in the region of 50 billion euros or 60 billion euros progressing, out of which only 40 billion euros, as I said for Basel 2.5. And so if you take that into account in the return on equity, it remains extremely over our LIBOR and well above the cost of equity, no doubt.
Okay. Thanks.
So we'll give the floor to the phone calls.
Yes.
We now have a question from Kinner Lakhani, Citigroup. Please go ahead.

Hi. Good afternoon. Just a quick follow-up, actually. On the ALM hedging that you do, especially around the retail franchises, I just wanted to try and understand if there has been any change in terms of the duration of your hedges, whether you have shortened those hedges. And secondly, are you seeing any kind of competition for retail funding? In the event that that happened, do you think that BNP would feel obliged to participate?

I cannot the second question, but I can for the first one. It's – there hasn't been any significant change, I would say. We always manage the balance with a long-term view. I mean a five, eight, ten years view. We mentioned that several times in the past already, on the discovering of the equity management today, and it has always been that way and it's no change at all.
Second question was...
Competition for banking.

For deposits? Yes, you can see from time to time, some banks, local banks or regional banks, or direct banks that are pushing a bit too far, I would say price is paid on deposit, but nothing that is as of today are going to change the business model for domestic retailers in France, Belgium or Italy.
We will now take our next question from , please go ahead.

Yes. Good afternoon and congratulations on Fortis bank. Fortis bank is becoming relatively overcapitalized, which will hit you in Basel III. So my question is what is your preferred or most realistic solution to that? What would you prefer to us to meet the dividend, if you renew acquisitions before in Turkey? Or do you want to acquire the remainder 25% of the government? Thank you.

Well I think that for the moment we certainly are ready to see a further, if there were like in Turkey, if there was an acquisition in some other territory where Fortis is active to be logical that that will be the vehicle. Regarding dividends it has to be decided with the other shareholder, and regarding buying back the minority stake of the Belgium government is not on the agenda. It's not yet on the agenda.
this year or is that not a possibility?
We have not decided anything in that sense or in that respect, so no more here and nothing much, nothing less.
Thanks again.
Okay.
. Please go ahead.
[Question inaudible]

Regarding your question, well, I don't see BNP Paribas as you can imagine as a banking monster. I see BNP Paribas as a large integrated and well managed organization in financial services. But certainly one of the reasons why we will – I will personally be cautious on significant acquisitions of significant size in the foreseeable future is we want to make sure we can, we can manage them, integrate them. And I think that size for size is certainly not. And getting bigger is not, is not really on our agenda.

As regard the management, as regard the cost of safety, we had very much increased, but like any bank we have made in terms of internal control, in terms of compliance, in terms of, well risk, market risk; we are very much increased going forth, both the stuff and the number of the full time – number of full time employees, and also the systems. And we are dedicating quite a strong – and I think at BNP Paribas you know Finance division and here's the CFO, the finance, the risk, the liquidity and the – and asset ability and also the compliance are very – these are very strong group functions that are really keeping I think a tight control over the organization. And we have – we have emphasized a lot this improvement as we have made very big investments in the last two, three years. And regarding...
[Question inaudible]

I can't translate it in constant commercial directly, but I'm sure that between compliance, audit and it's hundreds of full time employees, maybe like 1,000 that we have added in the last two, three years. So it is really very significant.

I think, by the way, you know, we've seen it at BancWest in California which is because it is a $50 billion U.S. dollar bank in terms of balance sheet, it is considered a complex organization. If you look at BancWest's investment in compliance and in complying with the new rules, there the cost has been in the whether it's $20 million, $25 million U.S. dollar. And it's not – it's also a big investment and BancWest does not sell these. So every bank around the world also independent of its size has seen its cost of control and its cost of being regulated increase. And I think this is a cost of doing business.

This is also, by the way, a barrier to entry into the industry that both with equity entering now the banking business from the capital, from an equity position as much as from compliance, regulatory, how to manage it, is really building to my view a formidable barrier to entry.

Getting back to your other question in comparison to AXA, we certainly are aware at BNP Paribas that we want to keep the right balance between I would say business line and geography. I want to make two concrete illustration. We nominated in January of this year, so a few weeks ago, for the first time a high-level BNP Paribas executive by the name of Eric Raynaud who is now posted in Hong Kong, between Hong Kong and Singapore, is the head, is the new head of Asia-Pacific, well, including actually Australia and Japan, and is the head for not only, he's not only CEO of BNP Paribas CIB platform for Asia-Pacific but he is also overlooking our investment solutions and even our smaller retail initiatives. And so we really have now in Hong Kong a member directly reporting to the executive committee and really empowered more than ever before that is posted in Hong Kong to manage our strategy.

And he will come back to the executive committee every two or three months to have a direct – and then he's directly reporting to the, well, to the general management, who is really – and this is quite new because we felt that in Asia we needed somebody with high, well, highly empowered sitting all the time out of Hong Kong, between Hong Kong and Singapore, but based in Hong Kong to manage the BNP Paribas strategy. And in terms of risk people, HR, he has, well, a small but let's say team of senior people working with him to make sure that out of Hong Kong we can manage our Asian operation.

And the same was, we made the same now the Everett Schenk, who is the head of our New York CIB operations out of New York. He's responsible for North America, which for us includes mainly Canada and the United States.

And so we have our key heads of regions have, I would say, more power and more responsibility than they had two or three years ago. So this is a tendency to move responsibilities to the key regions. I mentioned Asia, I mentioned New York and North America. I could also mention Brazil for Latin America, well, Louis Bazire, the head of Brazil is also a regional head. So this is a move that we have done and that we – so I think we agree in a sense that in the world we live we need, for a number of reasons we need to have key executives of BNP Paribas really make accountable and also in part to manage the implementation of our strategy in the different key regions of the world to answer your question.
Thank you very much.
Last question, okay. So thank you very much for your attention.
